content.description: This route is true to its title, with finicky gear placements all the way up a trending quartz dike. Start out in the thin seam just right of Colossus. Tip toe up the dike until the roof, where some mighty movements await with fairly marginal gear. The crux entails some gymnastic movement on jugs with wild knee scumming, and a desperate move off a pinch to the god send jug. Pull up onto headwall and tip toe up and right to Tarantulas anchors. Try and safe all your juice for the roof and above. All together, a VERY engaging climb and well worth a go!
content.protection:
singles .3-#3, doubles of #2 and small wires

Chains
content.location: squeezed between Tarantula and Colossus. Follow trending seam and quartz dike up to roof, where the business starts off!. Look for roof with large waco cut out left of directly left of Tarantula. Shares anchors with Tarantula.

content.description: Climb up to the roof passing two spaced out bolts on some easy climbing (no harder than 5.10+). Clip the third bolt on the headwall and duck back into the cave for a no-hands rest. Pull the roof and navigate up the headwall with super small crimps and one jug. Finish off on the chain anchors shared with Loch Ness Monster.
content.location: This route is located on the west side of Bath Rock and just right of Loch Ness Monster.

content.description: This route fires the center of the west face and is immediately left of Loch Ness.  The bolts leading up to the steep scoop are very run out, but can be supplemented with a few small cams in horizontal seams between the bolts.  At the beginning of the steep scoop, the climb angles up and slightly left through a thin overhanging crux on small crimps.  The sequence is difficult to unlock, but the moves are great and the route is classic City of Rocks enjoyment.
content.protection: Bolts and a few small cams 3/8" to 1/2" to place between the first few bolts.  Chain anchors on top.
content.location: Located directly left of Loch Ness.  The route climbs through the big overhanging dish of featureless looking rock.

content.description: AKA: Broken Face. Just left of Private Idaho is this face that is easily top-roped, after climbing Private Idaho.  Simple straight-forward C of R climbing.  A bit flaky.

Located on the back side of

Bath Rock

, just left of

Colossus

.

Classic Crack Climbing! Climb the obvious crack in the large open book. Move Left at the crux 70' up to keep it 5.9. Straight up might be slightly harder.

Edit: Apparently I got this wrong, don't go left or you will be cheating. Although going left is a lot of fun.
content.protection: Standard City of Rocks Rack. Nothing bigger than a #2 Camalot.

content.description: Easy steep slabs to a ledge suitable for considering your priorities. Pull through a wild roof move (think knee bar above the head, transitioning to something that can only be described as a "drop-knee-bar") and resume moderate climbing.
content.protection: Nothing until after the crux roof (30-40' off the deck), angle up left to the Coffee & Cornflakes / Scream Machine / To the Boys in Ketchum anchors. It is possible (and worth your time) to toprope from these chains, but make sure to place a directional to avoid a huge swing from the crux.
content.location: Furthest right route on the Rollercoaster wall, starting next to the wooden railing.

content.description: The obvious sport climb up the rib/roof.  Some gear is useful to get to the first bolt.  Follow the rib on the left side and traverse below the roof.  A few desperate slaps will set you up for pulling the bulge.  A hard traverse leads back left.  Get a rest and fire up the technical and pumpy finish.

An outstanding route with multiple cruxes. The name Gemini comes from a roller coaster at Lagoon in Utah, but it also suggests the route's two charactersâ€”thin razor edges to big jugs and vice versa.
content.protection: Bolted. Chain anchors at the top.
content.location: The route climbs the beautiful face between Donini's Crack and Coffee and Cornflakes.

content.description:
This is a classic tough roof crack on the back side of Bath Rock.  Many try this route, but but few succeed. It is probably a little bit of a sandbag.

Start below the obvious roof crack.  You can clip a bolt on Gemini 5.12a near the beginning.  Work up under the roof and fire in some thin hand gear.  If you are tall,  you can get a no hands sit down rest below the roof.

Jam the thin hand crack through the roof. (tape!!)  Face holds can be found on the left and right.  Picking the right moves and getting your feet in the crack, will gain a rest above the roof.  An easier hand crack leads to the bolt anchor on the sport climb to the left.

I heard a rumor that Donini came back and solo'ed this thing in his 60's.

climbs.name: Colossus
climbs.fa: R. Hong, M. Fischer, Pampe, Miles, Lightner, 1988

content.description: This is the most popular line on the back side of Bath.  Start just right of Private Idaho.  The climb trends left through a low roof.  The crux is pulling left through the large hueco at about 60ft.

AKA:

Scream Machine

This route is located on the far right side of the back side of

Bath Rock

. It is the bolted route two feet right of the actual

Coffee and Cornflakes (5.11X, 80's)

The first bolt is 35ft up.  If you start on the right there is no gear.  You can start as for

Donini's Crack

and clip the

Gemini

bolt on the way to the first bolt.

This is a fun steep 5.10, and very pumpy for the 5.10a grade.  3 or 4 bolts lead to a 2 bolt anchor.
